metadata.sermon_title: Little Resurrections After the Big One
metadata.notes: The sermon focuses on the confrontation between the early church and the Roman/Religious power structures.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher avoids moralizing or shaming the congregation. The 'judgment' is directed outward toward systemic 'superpowers' rather than inward at the listener's failures.
quotes: Does a good deed make you nervous because you did not authorize it?
This is the Jesus whom you executed as an enemy of the state.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The care is expressed through the lens of empowerment and restoration rather than pity or dependency.
quotes: We will do better than that. In the name of Jesus, stand up and walk.
The church has power to enact mini-resurrections.

adult.analysis: The preacher uses a high degree of Adult ego state to analyze the socio-political context of the text. He invites the listener to 'think about this' and 'imagine,' treating the congregation as thinking subjects capable of processing a 'contemporary story.'
quotes: I invite you to think about this...
The bold statement of Peter accomplished two things at the same time.
This is an ancient story; it is at the same time a contemporary story.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly encourages moving away from the 'Adapted Child' role (submission to the empire) toward a state of 'empowered obedience.'
quotes: Not at all cowed by or intimidated by imperial surveillance.
He mocks the authorities, because he is not intimidated.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a strong sense of the Free Child in the descriptions of 'leaping for joy' and the 'juices of life.' The preacher celebrates spontaneity and energy.
quotes: The lame beggar stood up and walked and leapt for joy.
God has unleashed into the world the juices of life and health and well-being.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher primarily provides a historical and theological framework, inviting the listener to observe the dynamics of power and then apply that observation to their own life. It is an invitation to autonomy.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Minimal. The sermon is remarkably transparent in its goal to shift the listener from a passive subject to an active agent.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: A slight risk of 'Ain't It Awful' regarding the 'Empire,' but it is mitigated by the call to action ('mini-resurrections').

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The sermon avoids games by refusing to play the Rescuer. Instead of saying 'I will save you,' the preacher says 'You are authorized to perform mini-resurrections.' It promotes Adult autonomy rather than Child dependency.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low. He points to the source of power (Jesus) rather than positioning himself as the one with the answers.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low. Only directed at abstract 'authorities' of the status quo, not the congregation.
preacher_roles.victim: None. The tone is one of empowerment, not complaint.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is invited out of the 'Victim' role (the lame beggar) into the role of the 'Empowered Actor' (Peter/John).
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon provides a clear exit from the triangle by emphasizing 'authorization' and 'autonomy' through the 'Big Resurrection'.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is psychologically robust and promotes high levels of autonomy. By utilizing an Adult ego state to analyze power structures, the preacher avoids the common trap of the Critical Parent (shaming the congregation) or the Rescuer (making the congregation dependent on the preacher's grace). The focus on 'mini-resurrections' encourages the Free Child's spontaneity and the Adult's agency. It successfully transforms a religious narrative into a framework for personal and social empowerment without resorting to manipulative 'Games.'
strengths: Empowers the listener rather than creating dependency.
Avoids the 'Bait and Switch' of law and grace.
areas_for_improvement: The 'Empire' is a broad target; more Adult specificity on how the 'status quo' manifests in the listener's immediate 'here-and-now' could further strengthen the reality-testing.
Ensure the 'mocking' of authorities doesn't slide into a 'NIGYSOB' game against political opponents.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue to use 'I invite you to think' and 'Imagine' as these are classic Adult-hooking phrases that prevent the listener from slipping into a passive Adapted Child state.
